current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend title 49, United States Code, to improve the
		  accessibility of entertainment programming provided by air carriers on
		  passenger flights, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail:
introduced
			 the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Commerce, Science, and
			 Transportation

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
) any foreign air carrier, shall ensure
				that—

text.#text:
In providing air transportation, an air carrier,
				including (subject to

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, all visually displayed entertainment programming available
				to passengers on a flight is accessible to individuals with disabilities,
				including by—

text.#text:
on and after the
				date that is 180 days after the date of the enactment of the

providing, or
				making available, open captioning for individuals with disabilities, including
				individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing, when such programming is available
				to passengers through shared video displays, such as a monitor located in a
				passenger access aisle;

providing, or
				making available, closed captioning for individuals with disabilities,
				including individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing, when such programming is
				available to passengers through individual video displays; and

providing, or
				making available, video description for individuals with disabilities,
				including individuals who are blind or visually impaired, when such programming
				is available to passengers through individual video displays or shared video
				displays; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, all
				individual video displays that display entertainment programming or information
				to passengers on a flight that are operated primarily by using touchscreens or
				other contact-sensitive controls include a mechanism that allows individuals
				with disabilities, including individuals who are blind or visually impaired, to
				independently operate the displays in accordance with the standards prescribed
				under

text.#text:
not later than
				the effective date of the regulations prescribed under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
of that section, shall be available to any person aggrieved by
				the failure of an air carrier to comply with

text.#text:
The remedies and
				procedures set forth in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , including the injunctive relief described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 308(a) of the Americans with Disabilities Act
				of 1990

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to the same
				extent that those provisions apply with respect to the compliance of covered
				entities with

text.#text: The provisions of

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall apply with
				respect to the compliance of air carriers with

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 308(b) of the
				Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990

header.#text:
Establishment
				of standards for operation of individual video displays

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance
				Board

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to ensure that such video displays include a mechanism that allows individuals
				with disabilities to operate the displays independently.

Not later than 18 months after the date of the enactment

quote.#tail:
) setting forth the minimum

text.#text:
Not
				later than 180 days after the

Architectural and Transportation Barriers

, shall periodically review
				and, as appropriate, amend the standards prescribed under
. Not later than 180 days after the

issues amended
				standards under this paragraph, the

text.#text: The

In
				this section:

term.#tail:
means a
				method, process, or mechanism, which may include a device, that—

text.#text: The term

allows an
				individual who is deaf or hard of hearing to have access to the content of
				visually displayed entertainment programming; and

allows that
				access by displaying, through an individual device or individually used
				technology, all of the audio portion of the programming (including displaying
				the dialogue and any narration, as well as descriptions of on- and off-screen
				sounds such as sound effects, music, or lyrics for music, and information
				identifying the character who is speaking) as text that can be effectively
				viewed and controlled by that individual while the individual simultaneously
				watches the programming.

term.#tail: means any person who has a disability as defined in

text.#text: The term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 3 of the Americans
				with Disabilities Act of 1990

term.#tail:
means a method,
				process, or mechanism that—

text.#text: The term

allows an
				individual who is deaf or hard of hearing to have access to the content of
				visually displayed entertainment programming; and

allows that
				access by openly displaying on the video display on which the programming is
				displayed all of the audio portion of the programming (including displaying the
				dialogue and any narration, as well as descriptions of on- and off-screen
				sounds such as sound effects, music, or lyrics for music, and information
				identifying the character who is speaking) as text that can be effectively
				viewed by that individual and other passengers while the individual and
				passengers simultaneously watch the programming.

term.#tail:
means a
				method, process, or mechanism, including a device, that—

text.#text: The term

allows an
				individual who is blind or visually impaired to have access to the key visual
				elements of visually displayed entertainment programming (such as actions,
				settings, facial expressions, costumes, and scene changes); and

allows that
				access through the provision of contemporaneous audio narrated descriptions of
				those elements during the natural pauses in the audio portion of the
				programming, or during the audio portion if necessary.

term.#tail:
means live televised events,
				recorded programming (including television programs), or motion pictures that
				are available to passengers, for a fee or without cost, on a flight in air
				transportation.

text.#text: The term
